episode.title: Federal Power Commission v. Texaco, Inc.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Wahrenbrock, you may -- I think you had finished -- you'd --

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: I believe I have two minutes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Alright.
Two minutes, I won't argue about that.

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: Well, in those two minutes, I think that it is an opportunity after having had a few moments to let the thoughts spill on over us as they have been coming at us for two hours.

To recollect that the key issue in this case is the power of an agency directed by a statute not to promulgate any rules going to either rights or contracts which will be effective in the future without holding a hearing and developing an evidentiary record.
The issue then is the power of that agency despite that statute to hold such a hearing that does not provide for a record or the development of those facts.
This was an issue that has come up once before.
It did not get as far as this Court but it was actively litigated in the District of Columbia Circuit.
Before 1960, the Federal Power Commission issued its general policy statement in which it promulgated prices for some 23 areas in the country.
And in that general policy statement, it provided for specific prices.
And the consumers of natural gas felt that they did not like those prices and they challenged the issuance of that policy statement in the Court of Appeals.
And there the court said, “But this is only a matter of policy.
There has been no hearing.
The Commission cannot promulgate prices without a hearing.
The avenues of recourse and the development of facts must be kept open as they are here under this policy statement.”
“But the statement, “said the court, “may stand.”
So, these rules may stand as policy only.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: How do you reconcile Wisconsin with your position?

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: The lower court in Wisconsin held exactly this --

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Not in the -- this Court on those general policy statements.

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: This Court merely affirmed what the lower court had said Your Honor that the policy statement prices were no more than guidelines just as the Tenth Circuit below here has permitted these prices that I held up earlier to be statements of the Commission's policy to let the industry know generally how the Commission feels about these clauses.
But obviously --

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: They are ceilings (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: Excuse me Your Honor?

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: They are in effect the ceiling on the price, aren't they?

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: The prices?

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: The -- general policy.

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: No, Your Honor, they are not.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: They won't let them file them by that ceiling?

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: Oh, they will -- they will permit a filing and they will permit hearings as to why you should have a right.
And this is the only reason that the court -- the District of Columbia Court, where the policy statement was specifically challenged permitted the policy statement to stand.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: This is just a guarantee that there's going to be a hearing.
And everybody knows that to file -- higher those rates, there's bound to be a hearing?

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.
And it was also where the consumers really got concerned about it was, that -- that it appeared, put on both a ceiling and a floor.

And they were concerned that if -- if a price filed below the ceiling were submitted to the Commission, the Commission would automatically stamp it and approve it and the Commission has not allowed that.
A challenge can be put in even for prices below the policy statement and a hearing held.
But as you say Mr. Justice White, if it's over, you're certainly going to get that hearing.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Well, I understood that the -- well, the policy statements say they fixed the price in a certain field.
Then they had applications subsequent to that that were in excess of that ceiling on that price.
That they reduce them to the ceiling price before they would certi -- certificate them.

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: No, Your Honor, yes and no.
Number one, the -- the policy statement did promulgate prices for certain producing areas rather than specific fields as they are designated in the industry.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Yes, just an area.

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: That within an area such as a certain large number of counties and railroad in Texas.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: They are (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: If you file for a price that exceeds the policy statement, make a certificate application, the Commission consolidates a great number of these applications and has the statutory hearing to determine the public convenience and necessity.
And it may condition the certificates if it -- on the basis of that record, finds that they do not need the test of the public convenience and necessity.
They do not reject your application in that instance.
The policy level is just that.
It is a policy.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Is that in addition to --

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: Excuse me Your Honor?

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: And that's your additional price.

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: But only when there is a record which will support it in a court of review which you have a right to, under Section 19 (b) of the Natural Gas Act, permits you to bring that record before a competent court of review to see whether there are findings which support the Commission in its cut.
And there must be findings of record and there must be facts of record to support the finding that a condition should issue.
And they have not just cut them to the policy level, Your Honor.
In some cases, the Commission had stated that the facts of record require even a further reduction in the policy.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: I understand, of course you'd have a right there to -- I suppose on the permanent -- permanent certifications to have a hearing, isn't it?

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: Absolutely.
And that hearing has been permitted in those cases but it has been permitted in the cases of these contract clauses.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Because that's a directive.
It operates directly on the price though, doesn't it?
Or rates, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: Well, the -- the certificate proceeding?

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: Yes.
Well, first of all, these clauses --

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: This doesn't operate directly on the rates.

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: These clauses go obviously directly to the price that you will be able to file for.
And secondly, the authority of the Commission over a contract and price is spelled out in the same sections of the Act.
They have no greater authority over price than they have over contract, exactly the same statutory limit is placed on them.
Price and contract appear in the same section of the Natural Gas Act in the same sentence.
There can be no greater authority over one than the other.
No -- no permission to do something without findings as to one but the necessity for findings as to the other.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Wisconsin case first speaks for itself.

But on page 299, that statement is what the case hold, not quite what you state because its -- Commission stated in that case absence of compelling evidence, it will certificate, an issue would raise and suspend increase of rates which exceeded those price level.

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: That's correct but you have the opportunity to put on the evidence, Your Honor.
The hearing is held and the evidence is taken.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: I suppose --

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: And in the absence of the compelling evidence, you -- you can't --

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Well, there's no -- there's no barrier into the statute for your company to propose rate at any time and get a hearing.

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: The very barrier is the fact that this rule and regulation --

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Is actually --

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: -- precludes us from having contracts that will permit us to come before the Commission.
This is our essential complaint Your Honor.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: You -- you -- you're talking about a contract, we're talking about rates.
I was talking about rates.

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: But -- well, the rate is the product of the contract terms that we have, Your Honor.
And as Mr. Justice White asked this morning --

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: What I'm -- comes back to whose -- was this an Act to -- for the protection of pipeline companies or is it the Act for protection of consumers?

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: Well, that it -- I don't see how the Commission can -- can ever protect the consumers if it is permitted.
If any agency is permitted to promulgate prices, contracts or anything else without evidence, without a hearing in which the consumer can appear to state what he thinks the price ought to be.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Of course your -- your only objection is that -- this right that there might be a deterioration in the Btu's that therefore, you'd have to readjust.
Is that your position?

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: Your Honor there --

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: That's -- that's a -- is that the only provision that you have in your contract that they've struck out?

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: No, not at all.

They had in our contract -- oh, we had in contract also, Your Honor, the result at the end of -- of 10 years and 15 years to negotiate -- renegotiate the contract price on the basis of quality, quantity and all the other pertinent provisions as to delivery conditions in the 10 and 15th year.

The problems which might come up as to costs of value of the commodity, the supply and demand situations, all of the facts which necessarily will go into a determination of the justness and reasonableness.
It's not just one clause that we're complaining about.

What must be remembered is that Commission has stricken all clauses, the fertility of the businessman's mind to provide for the sale of his commodity over 20, 30 or 40 years, has been completely set aside and he is restricted to the half page of pricing provisions which are spelled out in Order 232A, that were spelled out.
Well, this Commission still insist it doesn't know how or what is the test of a just and reasonable rate.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Of course, you could go under 4 and -- and (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: We have no contract rights, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: And after 20 years, you could.

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: In our case, we would be able to because our contract would expire and under the holding of this Court, we would be able to file.
Pan American does not have that situation as I'm sure you'll recall there is this, a life of production.
They would never --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What about a contract that's for 20 years, except that --- except that as in yours, the rate provision expires in 10?

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: The rate provision doesn't expire, Your Honor.
Here, they -- there is a fixed escalation.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: Each five years and the alternative --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Assuming you had a contract that's said at the end of 10 years, the -- this rate expires and we shall -- we will renegotiate it.

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: That's what Pan American has.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That's not permitted?

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: That's not permitted.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Well, if you make it 10 years.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: They can't make the contract for 10 years?

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: Because if you read these rules and regulations, Your Honor, you'll find that the Commission has also found in them that long term contracts, 20 years and more are in the public interest and are necessary in order to put together a pipeline project and have financing and then get gas to market.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But then --

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: So on one hand, we must have them but we can't have any (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, you have them in less than 20 years or don't you?

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: Once in a while, you'll get a distressed sale where you will have a small patch of gas and the pipeline will -- will take it at -- at some distressed price for a period of five years or something like that.
But normally, in any pipeline project, they have got to have affirmed commitment in order to get their certificate from the Commission.
And the Commission has normally -- these long term contracts are actually the product of regulation.

We have been given the requirement on one hand to negotiate a long term contract and had taken back on the other hand, the ability to get any flexibility, any sound business prospects for the future while we do this.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, Mr. Wahrenbrock.

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: Mr. Chief --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Wahrenbrock, before you begin, I want to (Inaudible) if I could ask you.
We wanted to find out why the Commission concluded that only those forms of chain clauses combined with 232 was good and everything else was bad, where will we go?

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: The Commissions rules Orders 232 -- 232A and 242 appear in the record in this case --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I -- I know they're here, but what -- where -- why -- where will we find the -- the groundwork upon which the conclusion is reached that this order ought to be in here?

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: Principally, in the Pure Oil decision of the Commission which was issued at the same day as Order number 232, the Pure Oil decision is reported in the Commission's reports in Volume 25, it's cited in our brief.
That -- the -- the Order 232 on page 13 of the record refers to the Pure Oil opinion as for the discussion of the problem with which the Commission was dealing.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Then that's starts to which this (Inaudible) terms --

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: Yes, I don't --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- to find out why this was done.

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: Yes.
Now I --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, that -- that suggests another question.
Then whatever record there maybe in 387 would not help this -- in this respect, correct?

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: 387 which was an attempt to review Order 242 itself directly.

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: 242, the last order --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: -- prescribing these regulations, in which the Tenth Circuit granted our motion to dismiss.
In that case, when our motion to dismiss was put over to the merits, we did then certify the record in the rulemaking proceeding in which 242 was issued.
Not the record in the rulemaking proceeding in which 232 was issued and not the or -- in the yet earlier rulemaking.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well then -- what then -- the answer is that the record on 242 would not be helpful to us, the 233?

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: There -- there -- only the record on 242 was certified in the other case to the Tenth Circuit.
The Tenth Circuit, we feel could in any of these cases, have judicially noticed that --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: No.
No, I'm sorry, I guess I'm not making myself clear.
I'm trying to find out whether there's anything in the record in 387 which as you said involves Review Order 242, will help us find out why the Commission promulgated 232.

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: That record does not contain Commission analysis -- Commission -- Commission appraisal.
It is the comments and data and arguments that were submitted.
And most of those comments and argument and data that were submitted were like the argument that is made here, it's argumentative.
There was no request by either of these petitioners in any of these rulemaking proceedings, in the rulemaking proceedings for a trial like hearing for an opportunity to present evidence.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I (Inaudible) -- but I'm still trying to make clear to myself at least --

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: I'm sorry, I've --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- while I look at to find out why the Commission promulgated this order.
Now, you told me if I look at the Pure Oil decision --

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- I'll find help there.

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Will I find anything in the record in 242 -- at 242 and find it in 387?

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: You will find there only the comments and data which were submitted in response to the invitation.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: As I know, it may not as a Board's appraisal which underlies the -- the 232.

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Alright.

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Where is the Board' appraisal except in the Pure Oil case?

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: In the -- Pure Oil and in the -- these three orders, 232 -- 232 --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Just in the text of the orders you've served.

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: That's right, yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Now, did the -- the Pure Oil case cover -- cover all types of proscribed contracts or all -- of all types of proscribed clauses?

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: The one that was immediately involved in the Pure Oil case was a -- a favored-nation clause.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That's right, that's right.

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: And that was the basis for the consideration of the general question of these indefinite clauses.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But to take -- take a provision where a contract provides for a definite price for 10 years and then the -- the price clause expires and there's a provision for renegotiation at the end of 10 years.

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Now, the Commission proscribes that.

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That is out, that's impermissible.

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: Now if --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But now --

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: It proscribes it if the basis for the redetermination are other prices that themselves have not been subjected to Commission scrutiny.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So that -- so that if -- if you had a contract that's set after 10 years, the rate shall be a just and reasonable rate.
Is that permitted, the -- your -- of your (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- its --

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: It's -- it's -- you're coming very close to the Memphis type of provision and that was --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: -- what I was going to start talking about because you had asked about that before.
That provision, that type of indefinite had never -- I think never been used, that was -- that was not known of.
It would -- we weren't aware of it.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Isn't that in a sense what they --

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: At the time --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- have here?

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: No, no.
Let me come to that.
The one we have here is for redetermination upon the basis of other prices at the time, an average of three, something of that kind.
Now, the Commission had not explicitly considered that in Pure Oil.
It invited comments after 232 so that in effect, there was another rulemaking proceeding.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: And 30 comments were received to argue this.
And on the basis of that, the Commission adhered to the position that it had originally taken, accepted and modified it to permit these -- these indefinites that are now permitted, redeterminations.
Once, not more than once in a five-year period if they are based on rates that the Commission has had a chance to look at and hasn't questioned.
Now --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But we --

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: Pan American can have what it wants at the -- in 8 -- in 1983 or in 1965, if it will provide that the redetermination shall be upon the basis of three jurisdictional rates or one, if they want to make it for that which the Commission has and which has been filed with the Commission and the Commission has not suspended it and hasn't been -- hasn't questioned it --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But on --

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: -- in a certificate case.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But on 242, the -- there is nothing available to show why the Commissioner arrived at this conclusion other than just the text of the order itself.

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: The text of the order, that's right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That's all.

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: Now that complies with Section 4 (b) of the admin -- the -- of the Administrative Procedure Act which says that in issuing the rules, the Commission shall state the basis of the rules and the purpose sought to be achieved.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Are you suggesting --

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: And there has been no suggestion that it did not.
In Order 242, state the basis or that it did not state the purpose.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But now, you suggested that these -- that the -- that the companies didn't request a trial-type hearing.
Are you -- are you suggesting that they had a right to request it or that it -- that he would've granted (Inaudible) --

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: It is what --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- accountability if they -- it would have been granted?

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: Under the Administrative Procedure Act, it is solely within the Commission's discretion whether two and if anyone asks it and there were -- and if there had been factual questions raised, the past practice of the Commission indicates that if a trial-type hearing is the best way to resolve that question, it will follow that method.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: For --

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: It has voluntarily done so and times passed.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: For a rulemaking -- for a rulemaking --

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- purposes?

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: Yes sir.
It has --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Is there any instance where this has had a trial (Inaudible)?

turn.speaker: howard_e_wahrenbrock
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Wahrenbrock
turn.text: I can't say them to you.

My definite impression and I've -- and I'm -- I'm sure that I could verify this, is that it has on occasion used trial like proceedings to resolve questions when it did not have to have a room at such proceeding so far as the statute was concerned.
It certainly can use that and whether that is an effective way of doing, so it will.

But here, the provision of the rules permitting petitions for waiver to be filed enables a company in the case of a Memphis-type provision or in the case of such a provision as Mr. Gilliam referred to for an adjustment on account of rising costs due to the necessity for eliminating contamination which may occur if they have circumstances like that that the Commission has not considered, that are not within the ambit of the -- of the general problem, which it has resolved or -- or which it was dealing with, then it can apply for a -- a waiver and the Commission will grant it an app -- a hearing as it has in the of the case of the -- the Memphis-type clause itself, which Atlantic presented in a petition for amendment -- for waiver of the rule.
And the fact that there has been delay in that Atlantic proceeding to which Mr. Gilliam referred as though this were a sham.

This was a run around, the Commission was giving the companies is I submit, perfectly explained by the fact that when the examiner took that case under consideration, he was immediately confronted by the fact that the rule which was sought to be waived was one which the Tenth Circuit has said was an invalid rule.
And the court examiner, I would suppose is waiting up to see what the outcome of this decision is.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Very well, Mr. --
